content.html: Does anyone actually think #Reddit's execs are going to go back to their investors and say "our users made us change our policy"? I'm pretty sure their investors would rather just keep doubling down and eventually wind up bankrupt than enter a world where Reddit has to respond to the wishes of its users or even moderators, because what happens here is going to set a precedent either way, and their investors have more than just Reddit to think about.
content.value: Does anyone actually think #Reddit's execs are going to go back to their investors and say "our users made us change our policy"? I'm pretty sure their investors would rather just keep doubling down and eventually wind up bankrupt than enter a world where Reddit has to respond to the wishes of its users or even moderators, because what happens here is going to set a precedent either way, and their investors have more than just Reddit to think about.

content.html: I think that's the thing people don't understand about corporations. They aren't people. They don't have survival instincts. Investors don't care if individual corporations live or die. They care only about their portfolio, present and future, and they can change their portfolio whenever they like.

content.html:
@freakazoid no but i also think that the blackouts are a good thing - execs can and will drive their website into the ground, but that doesn't mean they deserve the communities that have grown there

i know a fair number of people that have been rethinking their comfort level with the corporate-owned internet specifically because of this protest

content.html: @freakazoid Personally, I don't have a fuck to give about what the reddit execs do or don't do. I'm hoping the blackout creates enough friction that the communities I care about decide it's time migrate. To my mind, the blackouts are all about getting user attention on this, and building enough of a critical mass to make migration possible.

content.html:
@ebeth Oh, they certainly are. It *might* change their minds, but even more important they have high propaganda value. If Reddit does end up badly hurt, the folks organizing the blackouts can take at least partial credit. They've shown the power of the users.

I did not mean to make it sound like I thought the blackouts were pointless.
